Award.AwardTitle: Perturbation Pressure Variations Deduced from Earthscope's US Array
Award.AbstractNarration:
Observations of surface pressure perturbations have been used for decades to understand gravity waves, convective processes, and terrain-flow interactions. While pressure perturbations on all scales have been studied, there is a research gap between the emphasis on low amplitude, high frequency perturbations arising typically from local turbulent boundary layer processes and large amplitude, lower frequency ones that can propagate over large distances and often lead to damaging winds. The pressure perturbations and pressure gradients leading to wind ramps that affect wind energy tend to fall between these two extremes.

This research will take advantage of the deployment beginning in 2010 of pressure sensors on the NSF sponsored Earthscope seismic Transportable Array (US Array). The sensors were initially in the central United States and now beginning to be deployed after two years to the eastern United States. These pressure data at a sampling interval of 1 Hz at ~400 stations will be used to document pressure perturbations on temporal scales from seconds to days and spatial gradients and wave-like characteristics of such perturbations on spatial scales larger than ~150 km.

The specific objectives of this study are: (1) Improve access for the atmospheric research community to pressure data acquired by the US Array; (2) Develop climatologies at each observing site of pressure perturbations in terms of frequency and amplitude as a function of location, season, and time of day; (3) Assess the amplitudes of horizontal perturbation pressure gradients in the context of local, mesoscale, and synoptic-scale flows; (4) Determine regional differences in the characteristics of propagating pressure perturbations; and (5) Examine pressure perturbations arising from terrain-flow interactions and thermally forced systems. The local and regional climatologies, case studies, and composites generated as part of this study will be used to examine the interactions of the many physical processes leading to pressure perturbations, i.e., solar tides, mountain-flow interactions, convective systems, ducted gravity waves, water breeze systems, etc.

Intellectual Merit:
This research may potentially advance knowledge and understanding of the numerous physical processes that lead to the redistribution of mass in the atmosphere. While there has been considerable work on how surface pressure perturbations are generated and their impacts, there has no any systematic study of pressure perturbations over the broad range of relevant temporal scales (seconds to days) over a large region (in this case, the eastern half of the United States). This research and the knowledge gained from the study will be applicable to similar phenomenon around the world. The project builds on familiarity with the US Array project, computer science expertise in data analysis, mining, and visualization, and prior research in statistical analysis, data assimilation, water breeze systems, and boundary-layer processes in mountainous terrain.

Broader Impacts:
Improved access to the US Array pressure data will lead to increasing collaboration among researchers interested in a broad spectrum of research arising from applications of these data. Benefits for society at large include improved nowcasting and prediction of severe storms arising from many different types of weather situations and better utilizations of wind energy resources. The research and teaching activities of the lead PI are closely related and enable the direct infusion of research findings into undergraduate and graduate courses at the University of Utah and elsewhere. The project involves the support and mentoring of a postdoctoral fellow and a doctoral student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our research relied on the deployment beginning in 2010 of pressure sensors on the NSF-sponsored Earthscope seismic Transportable Array (US Array). Figure 1 highlights where the sensors were deployed originally and their later redeployment further east in the continental United States and now in Alaska. Our research involved collaboration between atmospheric scientists, seismologists, and computer scientists. This research has extended the reach of the NSF-supported US Array project from its seismic origins to the atmospheric sciences. Five refereed publications, over a dozen presentations at national conferences, and two graduate theses have been used to disseminate research results that are aligned with the interdisciplinary goals of the NSF EarthCube program.

Pressure observations at hundreds of locations in the central and eastern continental United States were used to document changes in pressure that are often associated with damaging winds and other hazardous weather that affect lives and property. Figure 2 illustrates the ability to detect rapid pressure changes using the very high resolution (every second) US Array observations that is missed if pressure is sampled only every 20 or 60 minutes. As shown in Figure 3, case studies of strong pressure changes were analyzed using web tools developed to visualize and track tens of thousands of such events with respect to archived radar imagery and surface wind observations.

As a result of this project, current and retrospective US Array pressure data are now available to the operational weather community for use in nowcasting and numerical weather prediction. The public as well as the research and educational communities are able to access the data through web services (mesowest.utah.edu and synopticlabs.org) and the Research Data Archive at the National Center for Atmospheric Research. The pressure and additional weather observations from all-in-one sensors included as part of the deployment strategy for US Array stations in Alaska is proving highly beneficial to the operational needs of the fire weather community in that state. The level of access to the real-time and quality-controlled data that we have created for diverse applications is unusual compared to most research studies.

The results of this study combined with improvements nationwide in real-time access to pressure observations highlight the potential for improved detection and nowcasting of high-impact weather features. For example, the algorithms developed for this project  could be applied to output from weather prediction models such as the High Resolution Rapid Refresh data assimilation and forecast system to improve forecasting of high impact weather events that affect lives, property, and industry. The methodologies developed as part of this study to track pressure features may also be useful for a variety of other applications including boundary-layer wind ramp forecasting, a critical and difficult forecasting challenge at the present time for the wind energy industry.

Extensive graduate student and postdoctoral training and development took place as part of this project leading to the awarding of a Ph.D. degree in 2016 and nearly completed requirements for a M.S. degree in 2017. In addition, a postdoctoral fellow transitioned  to assistant research professor in part in recognition of his work for this project. A graduate student in the School of Computing also collaborated on this project. All of the web resources developed as part of this project are accessible for STEM education and training and many have been used for a variety of purposes by undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Utah and elsewhere.
